title: Liemar
text:
Liemar (unknown – 16 May 1101, in Bremen) was <a href="archbishop%20of%20Hamburg-Bremen">archbishop of Hamburg-Bremen</a> from 1072 to 1101, and an important figure of the early <a href="Investiture%20Contest">Investiture Contest</a>.
He was a supporter of <a href="Emperor%20Henry%20IV">Emperor Henry IV</a> from 1073. In 1074 the <a href="papal%20legate">papal legate</a>s <a href="Gerald%20of%20Ostia">Gerald of Ostia</a> and <a href="Hubert%20of%20Palestrina">Hubert of Palestrina</a> put pressure on him to hold a local <a href="synod">synod</a>; he resisted, was suspended, and by 1075 his views against papal interference with bishops had hardened. In 1080, he attended the <a href="Synod%20of%20Brixen">Synod of Brixen</a> that condemned <a href="Pope%20Gregory%20VII">Pope Gregory VII</a>. With <a href="Benno%20II%20of%20Osnabr%C3%BCck">Benno II of Osnabrück</a> he commissioned the anti-papal polemic of <a href="Wido%20of%20Osnabr%C3%BCck">Wido of Osnabrück</a> around 1085. Liemar was one of many bishops who was irked by Gregory VII's encroachment of episcopal autonomy. In a letter to Bishop Hezilo of Hildesheim, Liemar complained that Gregory VII was ordering his bishops about 'as though they were his bailiffs'.
